title: Qigong - Wikipedia
author: Authority control National Germany Israel United States Japan Czech Republic
cleaned_text: [[1]](#cite_note-1) qi gong, chi kung, of coordinated body-posture and movement, breathing, and meditation [[2]](#cite_note-nccih16-2) used for the purposes of health, spirituality, and martial-arts training. [[3]](#cite_note-3) With roots in [Chinese medicine](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_Medicine), [philosophy](/wiki/Chinese_philosophy), and [martial arts](/wiki/Chinese_martial_arts), qigong is traditionally viewed by the Chinese and throughout Asia as a practice to cultivate and balance [qi](/wiki/Qi) (pronounced approximately as "chee"), translated as "life energy". [[4]](#cite_note-Cohen-4) Qigong practice typically involves moving meditation, coordinating slow-flowing movement, deep rhythmic breathing, and a calm meditative state of mind. People practice qigong throughout China and worldwide for recreation, exercise, relaxation, preventive medicine, self-healing, [alternative medicine](/wiki/Alternative_medicine), meditation, self-cultivation, and chi) primarily means air, gas or breath but is often translated as a metaphysical concept of 'vital energy', [[4]](#cite_note-Cohen-4) referring to a supposed energy circulating through the body; though a more general definition is universal energy, including heat, light, and electromagnetic energy; [[5]](#cite_note-YJM1-5) and definitions often involve breath, air, gas, or the relationship between matter, energy, and spirit. [[6]](#cite_note-6) Qi is the central underlying principle in traditional Chinese [medicine](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine) and [martial arts](/wiki/Chinese_martial_arts). Gong (or kung) is often translated as cultivation or work, and definitions include practice, skill, mastery, merit, achievement, service, result, or accomplishment, and is often used to mean [gongfu](/wiki/Kung_fu_(term)) (kung fu) in the traditional sense of achievement through great effort. [[7]](#cite_note-7) The two words are combined to describe systems to cultivate and balance life energy, especially for health and wellbeing. [[4]](#cite_note-Cohen-4) The term qigong as currently used was promoted in the late 1940s through the 1950s to refer to a broad range of Chinese self-cultivation exercises, and to emphasize [health](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine) and [scientific](/wiki/History_of_science_and_technology_in_China) approaches, and origins[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=2)] With roots in ancient Chinese culture dating back more than 2,000 years, a wide variety of qigong forms have developed within different segments of Chinese society: [[11]](#cite_note-YJM2-11) in [traditional Chinese medicine](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine) for preventive and curative functions; [[12]](#cite_note-Holland-12) in [Confucianism](/wiki/Confucianism) to promote longevity and improve moral character; [[4]](#cite_note-Cohen-4) in [Taoism](/wiki/Taoism) and [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism) as [[13]](#cite_note-LWW-13) and in [Chinese martial arts](/wiki/Chinese_martial_arts) to enhance self defending abilities. [[9]](#cite_note-yeyoung_qigong_origin-9) [[14]](#cite_note-YJM3-14) Contemporary qigong blends diverse and sometimes disparate traditions, in particular the [Taoist meditative "guiding and pulling" ( [Daoyin](/wiki/Daoyin) ). Traditionally, qigong was taught by master to students through training and [oral transmission](/wiki/Oral_tradition), with an emphasis on meditative practice by scholars and gymnastic or dynamic practice by the working masses. [[15]](#cite_note-miura_1989-15) Starting in the late 1940s and the 1950s, the mainland Chinese government tried to integrate disparate qigong approaches into one coherent system, with the intention of establishing a firm scientific basis for qigong practice. In 1949, Liu Guizhen established the name "Qigong" to refer to the system of life-preserving practices that he and his associates developed, based on Dao yin and other philosophical traditions. [[16]](#cite_note-16) This attempt is considered by some [sinologists](/wiki/Sinology) as the start of the modern or scientific interpretation of qigong. [[17]](#cite_note-Otehode-17) [[18]](#cite_note-Despeux-18) [[19]](#cite_note-Nancy-19) During [Cultural Revolution](/wiki/Cultural_Revolution) (1966-1976), qigong, along with other traditional Chinese medicine, was under tight control with limited access among the general public, but was encouraged in state-run rehabilitation centers and spread to universities and hospitals. After the Cultural Revolution, qigong, along with [t'ai chi](/wiki/T%27ai_chi_ch%27uan), was popularized as daily morning exercise practiced en masse throughout China. Popularity of qigong grew rapidly during the [Deng](/wiki/Deng_Xiaoping) and [Jiang](/wiki/Jiang_Zemin) eras after [Mao Zedong's](/wiki/Mao_Zedong) death in 1976 through the 1990s, with estimates of between 60 and 200 million practitioners throughout China. Along with popularity and state sanction came controversy and problems: claims of extraordinary abilities bordering on the supernatural, [pseudoscience](/wiki/Pseudoscience) explanations to build credibility, [[20]](#cite_note-pseudoscience1-20) a mental condition labeled [qigong deviation](/wiki/Qigong_deviation), [[19]](#cite_note-Nancy-19) formation of cults, and exaggeration of claims by masters for personal benefit. [[8]](#cite_note-Palmer-8) [[21]](#cite_note-Wanjek-21) In 1985, the state-run National Qigong Science and Research Organization was established to regulate the nation's qigong denominations. [[22]](#cite_note-autogenerated4-22) In 1999, in response to widespread revival of old traditions of spirituality, morality, and mysticism, and perceived challenges to State control, the Chinese government took measures to enforce control of public qigong practice, including shutting down qigong clinics and hospitals, and banning groups such as [Zhong Gong](/wiki/Zhong_Gong) and [Falun Gong](/wiki/Falun_Gong). [[10]](#cite_note-Ownby-10): 161-174 [[23]](#cite_note-Penny-23) Since the 1999 crackdown, qigong research and practice have only been officially supported in the context of health and traditional Chinese medicine. The Chinese Health Qigong Association, established in 2000, strictly regulates public qigong practice, with limitation of public gatherings, requirement of state approved training and certification of instructors, and restriction of practice to state-approved forms. [[24]](#cite_note-Karchmer-24) [[25]](#cite_note-25) Through the forces of migration of the [Chinese diaspora](/wiki/Chinese_diaspora), [tourism in China](/wiki/Tourism_in_China), and [globalization](/wiki/Globalization), the practice of qigong spread from the Chinese community to the world. Today, millions of people around the world practice qigong and believe in the benefits of qigong to varying degrees. Similar to its historical origin, those interested in qigong come from diverse backgrounds and practice it for different reasons, including Qigong comprises a diverse set of practices that coordinate body (), breath (), and mind () based on Chinese philosophy. [[26]](#cite_note-A_Standard_Guide_on_Qigong_-26) [[27]](#cite_note-27) Practices include moving and still meditation, massage, chanting, sound meditation, and non-contact treatments, performed in a broad array of body postures. Qigong is commonly classified into two foundational categories: 1) dynamic or active qigong (dong gong), with slow flowing movement; and 2) meditative or passive qigong (jing gong), with still positions and inner movement of the breath. [[28]](#cite_note-Micozzi2010-28): 21770-21772 From a therapeutic perspective, qigong can be classified into two systems: 1) internal qigong, which focuses on self-care and self-cultivation, and; 2) external qigong, which involves treatment by a therapist who directs or transmits qi. [[28]](#cite_note-Micozzi2010-28): 21777-21781 As moving meditation, qigong practice typically coordinates slow stylized movement, deep diaphragmatic breathing, and calm mental focus, with visualization of guiding qi through the body. While implementation details vary, generally qigong forms can be characterized as a mix of four types of practice: dynamic, static, meditative, and activities requiring external aids. - Dynamic practice - involves fluid movement, usually carefully choreographed, coordinated with breath and awareness. Examples include the slow stylized movements of [T'ai chi ch'uan](/wiki/T%27ai_chi_ch%27uan), [Baguazhang](/wiki/Baguazhang), and [Xing Yi Quan](/wiki/Xing_Yi_Quan). [[29]](#cite_note-yang_taiji-29)Other examples include graceful movement that mimics the motion of animals in Five Animals ( [Wu Qin Xi qigong](/wiki/Wu_Qin_Xi)), [[30]](#cite_note-five_animals1-30)[ Goose (Dayan) Qigong. [[32]](#cite_note-32) [[33]](#cite_note-33)As a form of gentle exercise, qigong is composed of movements that are typically repeated, strengthening and stretching the body, increasing fluid movement (blood, synovial, and lymph), enhancing balance and [proprioception](/wiki/Proprioception), and improving the awareness of how the body moves through space. [[34]](#cite_note-Frantzis-34) - Static practice - involves holding postures for sustained periods of time. [[35]](#cite_note-35)In some cases this bears resemblance to the practice of [Yoga](/wiki/Yoga)and its continuation in the Buddhist tradition. [[36]](#cite_note-36)For example [Yiquan](/wiki/Yiquan), a Chinese martial art derived from [xingyiquan](/wiki/Xingyiquan), emphasizes static stance training. [[37]](#cite_note-37)In another example, the healing form Eight Pieces of Brocade ( [Baduanjin qigong](/wiki/Baduanjin_qigong)) is based on a series of static postures. [[38]](#cite_note-Yang-Eight-38) - Meditative practice - utilizes breath awareness, visualization, [mantra](/wiki/Mantra), chanting, sound, and focus on philosophical concepts such as qi circulation, aesthetics, or moral values. [[39]](#cite_note-39)In traditional Chinese medicine and Daoist practice, the meditative focus is commonly on cultivating qi in [dantian](/wiki/Dantian)energy centers and balancing qi flow in [meridian](/wiki/Meridian_(Chinese_medicine))and other pathways. In various Buddhist traditions, the aim is to still the mind, either through outward focus, for example on a place, or through inward focus on the breath, a mantra, a [koan](/wiki/Koan), emptiness, or the idea of the eternal. In the Confucius scholar tradition, meditation is focused on humanity and virtue, with the aim of self-enlightenment. [[11]](#cite_note-YJM2-11) - Use of external agents - Many systems of qigong practice include the use of external agents such as ingestion of herbs, massage, physical manipulation, or interaction with other living organisms. [[13]](#cite_note-LWW-13)For example, specialized food and drinks are used in some medical and Daoist forms, whereas massage and body manipulation are sometimes used in martial arts forms. In some medical systems a qigong master uses non-contact treatment, purportedly guiding qi through his or her own body into the body of another person. [[40]](#cite_note-Xu-40) Forms[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=5)] There are numerous qigong forms. 75 ancient forms that can be found in ancient literature and also 56 common or contemporary forms have been described in a qigong compendium. [[41]](#cite_note-MaJiRen1992-41): 203-433 The list is by no means exhaustive. Many contemporary forms were developed by people who had recovered from their illness after qigong practice. Most of the qigong forms come under the following categories:[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] - Medical qigong - Martial qigong - Spiritual qigong - Intellectual qigong - Life nourishing qigong Development of "health qigong"[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=6)] In 1995, there was Qigong Talent Bank, an organization of Science Research of Chinese Qigong, functioning as network system of the senior Chinese qigong talents in China. In order to promote qigong exercises in a standardised and effective way with a scientific approach, The Chinese Health Qigong Association (CHQA) appointed panels of Qigong experts, Chinese medicine doctors and sport science professors from different hospitals, universities and qigong lineage across China to research and develop new sets of qigong exercises. In 2003 the CHQA officially promoted a new system called "health qigong", which consisted of four newly developed health qigong Xi ). [Health Qigong Six Healing Sounds](/wiki/Liu_Zi_Jue)(Health Qigong Liu Zi Jue ). [Health Qigong Eight Pieces of Brocade](/wiki/Baduanjin_qigong)(Health Qigong Ba Duan Jin ). In 2010, the Chinese Health Qigong Association officially introduced five additional health qigong forms: [[42]](#cite_note-CHQA2-42) - Health Qigong: Taiji Yang Sheng Zhang (); a traditional Tai Chi Chuan form utilizing a [walking stick](/wiki/Walking_stick). - Health Qigong: Shi-Er Duan Jin (); (12) seated exercises to strengthen the neck, shoulders, waist, and legs. - Health Qigong: Daoyin Yang Sheng Gong Shi-Er Fa (); (12) routines from Daoyin tradition of guiding and pulling qi. - Health Qigong: Mawangdui Daoyin Shu (); technique for guiding qi along the meridians with synchronous movement and awareness. - Health Qigong: Da Wu (); choreographed dance-like exercises to lubricate joints and guide qi. Other commonly practised qigong styles and forms include: - Soaring Crane Qigong [[43]](#cite_note-43) [Wisdom Healing (Zhineng) Qigong](/w/index.php?title=Wisdom_Healing_(Zhineng)_Qigong&action=edit&redlink=1) [[44]](#cite_note-Gu-44) - Pan Gu Mystical Qigong [[45]](#cite_note-45) - Wild Goose (Dayan) Qigong [[46]](#cite_note-46) - Dragon and Tiger Qigong [[47]](#cite_note-47) [Primordial Qigong (Wujigong)](/wiki/Primordial_qigong) [[49]](#cite_note-49) - Chilel Phoenix Qigong [[51]](#cite_note-51) - Yuan Qigong [[52]](#cite_note-52) - Zhong Yuan Qigong [[53]](#cite_note-bookZYQ-53) Techniques[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=7)] Whether viewed from the perspective of exercise, health, philosophy, or martial arts training, several main principles emerge concerning the practice of qigong: [[4]](#cite_note-Cohen-4) [[34]](#cite_note-Frantzis-34) [[54]](#cite_note-Garripoli-54) [[55]](#cite_note-55) - Intentional movement: careful, flowing balanced style - Rhythmic breathing: slow, deep, coordinated with fluid movement - Awareness: calm, focused meditative state - Visualization: of qi flow, philosophical tenets, aesthetics - Chanting/Sound: use of sound as a focal point Additional principles: - Softness: soft gaze, expressionless face - Solid Stance: firm footing, erect spine - Relaxation: relaxed muscles, slightly bent joints - Balance and Counterbalance: motion over the center of gravity Advanced goals: - Equanimity: more fluid, more relaxed - Tranquility: empty mind, high awareness - Stillness: smaller and smaller movements, eventually to complete stillness The most advanced practice is generally considered to be with little or no motion. Traditional and classical theory[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=8)] Over time, five distinct traditions or schools of qigong developed in China, each with its own theories and characteristics: Chinese [Medical Qigong](/w/index.php?title=Medical_Qigong&action=edit&redlink=1), Daoist Qigong, Buddhist Qigong, Confucian Qigong, and Martial Qigong. [[56]](#cite_note-Liu2013CMQ-56): 30-80 All of these qigong traditions include practices intended to cultivate and balance qi. [[11]](#cite_note-YJM2-11) [[57]](#cite_note-57) [[58]](#cite_note-58) [[59]](#cite_note-59) Traditional Chinese medicine[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=9)] The theories ancient Chinese qigong include the [Yin-Yang](/wiki/Yin-Yang) and [Five Phases](/wiki/Wuxing_(Chinese_philosophy)) Theory, [Essence](/wiki/Jing_(Chinese_medicine))-Qi- [Spirit](/wiki/Shen_(Chinese_religion)) Theory, Zang-Xiang Theory, and Meridians and Qi-Blood Theory, which have been synthesized as part of [Traditional Chinese Medicine (TCM)](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine). [[56]](#cite_note-Liu2013CMQ-56): 45-57 TCM focuses on tracing and correcting underlying disharmony, in terms of deficiency and excess, using the complementary and opposing forces of [yin and yang](/wiki/Yin_and_yang) (), to create a balanced flow of qi. Qi is believed to be cultivated and stored in three main [dantian](/wiki/Dantian) energy centers and to travel through the body along twelve main [meridians](/wiki/Meridian_(Chinese_medicine)) (Jng Luò ), with numerous smaller branches and tributaries. The main meridians correspond to [twelve main organs )](/wiki/Zang_Fu) (Zàng f ). Qi is balanced in terms of [yin and yang](/wiki/Yin_and_yang) in the context of the traditional system of Five Phases (Wu xing ). [[11]](#cite_note-YJM2-11) [[12]](#cite_note-Holland-12) It is understood that illness and disease becomes apparent when qi becomes diminished or unbalanced or stagnant. Health is believed to be returned and maintained by rebuilding qi, eliminating qi blockages, and correcting qi imbalances. These TCM concepts do not translate readily to modern science and medicine but are used in conjunction in Hospitals throughout East Asia. [[60]](#cite_note-60) Daoism[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=10)] In [Daoism](/wiki/Taoism), various practices now known as Daoist qigong are claimed to provide a way to achieve [longevity](/wiki/Longevity) and spiritual [enlightenment](/wiki/Enlightenment_(spiritual)), [[61]](#cite_note-61) as well as a closer connection with the natural world. [[62]](#cite_note-62) For instance, the [Ming dynasty](/wiki/Ming_dynasty) compendium [Chifeng sui](/wiki/Chifeng_sui), Buddhism[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=11)] In [Buddhism](/wiki/Buddhism_in_China) meditative practices now known as Buddhist qigong are part of a spiritual path that leads to [spiritual enlightenment](/wiki/Enlightenment_(spiritual)) or [Buddhahood](/wiki/Buddhahood). [[63]](#cite_note-63) Confucianism[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=12)] In [Confucianism](/wiki/Confusianism) practices now known as Confucian qigong provide a means to become a [Junzi](/wiki/Junzi) () through awareness of [morality](/wiki/Morality). [[64]](#cite_note-64) [[65]](#cite_note-65) Contemporary qigong[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=13)] In contemporary China, the emphasis of qigong practice has shifted away from traditional philosophy, spiritual attainment, and folklore, and increasingly to health benefits, traditional medicine and martial arts applications, and a scientific perspective. [[8]](#cite_note-Palmer-8) [[10]](#cite_note-Ownby-10) Qigong is now practiced by millions worldwide, primarily for its health benefits, though many practitioners have also adopted traditional [philosophical](/wiki/Chinese_philosophy), [medical](/wiki/Traditional_Chinese_medicine), or [martial arts](/wiki/Chinese_martial_arts) perspectives, and even use the long [history of qigong](/wiki/Qigong_history) as evidence of its effectiveness. [[11]](#cite_note-YJM2-11) [[54]](#cite_note-Garripoli-54) Contemporary Chinese medical qigong[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=14)] Qigong has been recognized as a "standard medical technique" in China since 1989, and is sometimes included in the medical curriculum of major universities in China. [[66]](#cite_note-Wengell2008-66): 34 The 2013 English translation of the official Chinese Medical Qigong textbook used in China [[56]](#cite_note-Liu2013CMQ-56): iv, 385 defines CMQ as "the skill of body-mind exercise that integrates body, breath, and mind adjustments into one" and emphasizes that qigong is based on "adjustment" (tiao , also translated as "regulation", "tuning", or "alignment") of body, breath, and mind. [[56]](#cite_note-Liu2013CMQ-56): 16-18 As such, qigong is viewed by practitioners as being more than common physical exercise, because qigong combines postural, breathing, and mental training in one to produce a particular psychophysiological state of being. [[56]](#cite_note-Liu2013CMQ-56): 15 While CMQ is still based on traditional and classical theory, modern practitioners also emphasize the importance of a strong scientific basis. [[56]](#cite_note-Liu2013CMQ-56): 81-89 According to the 2013 CMQ textbook, physiological effects of qigong are numerous, and include improvement of respiratory and cardiovascular function, and possibly neurophysiological function. [[56]](#cite_note-Liu2013CMQ-56): 89-102 Conventional medicine[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=15)] Especially since the 1990s, conventional or mainstream Western medicine often strives to heed the model of [evidence-based medicine](/wiki/Evidence-based_medicine), EBM, which demotes medical theory, clinical experience, and physiological data to prioritize the results of controlled, and especially randomized, clinical trials of the treatment itself. [[67]](#cite_note-Sackett96-67) [[68]](#cite_note-68) Although some clinical trials support qigong's effectiveness in treating conditions diagnosed in Western medicine, the quality of these studies is mostly low and, overall, their results are mixed. [[69]](#cite_note-Lee2011-69) Integrative, complementary, and alternative medicine[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=16)] Integrative medicine (IM) refers to "the blending of conventional and complementary medicines and therapies with the aim of using the most appropriate of either or both modalities to care for the patient as a whole", [[70]](#cite_note-Kotsirilos2011-70): 455-456 whereas complementary is using a non-mainstream approach together with conventional medicine, while alternative is using a non-mainstream approach in place of conventional medicine. [[71]](#cite_note-NIHNCCAM2013-71) Qigong is used by integrative medicine practitioners to complement conventional medical treatment, based on complementary and alternative medicine interpretations of the effectiveness and safety of qigong. [[28]](#cite_note-Micozzi2010-28): 22278-22306 Scientific basis[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=17)] Scientists interested in qigong have sought to describe or verify the effects of qigong, to explore mechanisms of effects, to form scientific theory with respect to qigong, and to identify appropriate research methodology for further study. [[56]](#cite_note-Liu2013CMQ-56): 81-89 In terms of traditional theory, the existence of qi has not been independently verified in an experimental setting. [[72]](#cite_note-NCCAM-72) In any case, some researches have reported effects on pathophysiological parameters of biomedical interest. [[73]](#cite_note-:0-73) [[74]](#cite_note-Jahnke_et_al_2010-74) Practitioners, uses and cautions[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=18)] Recreation and popular use[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=19)] People practice qigong for many different reasons, including [recreation](/wiki/Recreation), [exercise](/wiki/Physical_exercise) and [training for martial arts](/wiki/Chinese_martial_arts). Practitioners range from athletes to people with disabilities. Because it is low impact and can be done lying, sitting, or standing, qigong is accessible for people with disabilities, seniors, and people recovering from injuries. [[4]](#cite_note-Cohen-4) Therapeutic use[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=20)] Therapeutic use of qigong is directed by TCM, CAM, integrative medicine, and other health practitioners. In China, where it is considered a "standard medical technique", [[66]](#cite_note-Wengell2008-66): 34 [ [better source needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:NOTRS)] qigong is commonly[ [citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed)] prescribed to treat a wide variety of conditions, and clinical applications include [hypertension](/wiki/Hypertension), Outside China qigong is used in [integrative medicine](/wiki/Integrative_medicine) to complement or supplement accepted medical treatments, including for [relaxation](/wiki/Relaxation_technique), [fitness](/wiki/Physical_exercise), [rehabilitation](/wiki/Physical_therapy), and treatment of specific conditions. [[70]](#cite_note-Kotsirilos2011-70) [[75]](#cite_note-Kuntsler2010-75) However, there is no high-quality evidence that qigong is actually effective for these conditions. [[76]](#cite_note-hartley-76) Based on [systematic reviews](/wiki/Systematic_review) of [clinical research](/wiki/Clinical_research), there is insufficient [evidence](/wiki/Evidence-based_medicine) for the effectiveness of using qigong as a therapy for any medical condition. [[2]](#cite_note-nccih16-2) [[69]](#cite_note-Lee2011-69) Safety and cost[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=21)] Qigong is generally viewed as safe. [[77]](#cite_note-77) No adverse effects have been observed in clinical trials, such that qigong is considered safe for use across diverse populations. Cost for self-care is minimal, and cost efficiencies are high for group delivered care. [[74]](#cite_note-Jahnke_et_al_2010-74) Typically the cautions associated with qigong are the same as those associated with any physical activity, including risk of muscle strains or sprains, advisability of stretching to prevent injury, general safety for use alongside conventional medical treatments, and consulting with a physician when combining with conventional treatment. [[2]](#cite_note-nccih16-2) [[78]](#cite_note-78) Clinical research[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=22)] Overview[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=23)] Although there is ongoing [clinical research](/wiki/Clinical_research) examining the potential health effects of qigong, there is little financial or medical incentive to support high-quality research, and still only a limited number of studies meet accepted medical and scientific standards of [randomized controlled trials (RCTs)](/wiki/Randomized_controlled_trial). [[2]](#cite_note-nccih16-2) [[74]](#cite_note-Jahnke_et_al_2010-74) Clinical research concerning qigong has been conducted for a wide range of medical conditions, including [bone density](/wiki/Bone_density), [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=24)] A 2009 systematic review on the effect of qigong exercises on reducing pain concluded that "the existing trial evidence is not convincing enough to suggest that internal qigong is an effective modality for pain management." [[79]](#cite_note-LeeIntPain2009-79) A 2010 systematic review of the effect of qigong exercises on [cancer](/wiki/Cancer) treatment concluded "the effectiveness of qigong in cancer care is not yet supported by the evidence from rigorous clinical trials." [[80]](#cite_note-LeeCancer2010-80) A separate systematic review that looked at the effects of qigong exercises on various physiological or psychological outcomes found that the available studies were poorly designed, with a high risk of bias in the results. Therefore, the authors concluded, "Due to limited number of RCTs in the field and methodological problems and high risk of bias in the included studies, it is still too early to reach a conclusion about the efficacy and the effectiveness of qigong exercise as a form of health practice adopted by the cancer patients during their curative, palliative, and rehabilitative phases of the cancer journey." [[81]](#cite_note-81) A 2011 overview of [systematic reviews](/wiki/Systematic_reviews) of controlled clinical trials, Lee et al. concluded that "the effectiveness of qigong is based mostly on poor quality research" and "therefore, it would be unwise to draw firm conclusions at this stage." [[69]](#cite_note-Lee2011-69) Although a 2010 [comprehensive literature review](/wiki/Literature_review) found 77 peer-reviewed [RCTs](/wiki/Randomized_controlled_trial), [[74]](#cite_note-Jahnke_et_al_2010-74) Lee et al.'s overview of systematic reviews as to particular health conditions found problems like sample size, lack of proper control groups, with lack of [blinding](/wiki/Blind_study) associated with high risk of bias. [[69]](#cite_note-Lee2011-69) A 2015 systematic review of the effect of qigong exercises on [cardiovascular diseases](/wiki/Cardiovascular_diseases) and [hypertension](/wiki/Hypertension) found no conclusive evidence for effect. [[76]](#cite_note-hartley-76) Also in 2015, a systemic review into the effects on hypertension suggested that it may be effective, but that the evidence was not conclusive because of the poor quality of the trials it included, and advised more rigorous research in the future. [[82]](#cite_note-82) Another 2015 systematic review of qigong on [biomarkers](/wiki/Biomarker) of cardiovascular disease concluded that some trials showed favorable effects, but concludes, "Most of the trials included in this review are likely to be at high risk of bias, so we have very low confidence in the validity of the results. [[76]](#cite_note-hartley-76) Mental health[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=25)] Many claims have been made that qigong can benefit or ameliorate mental health conditions, [[74]](#cite_note-Jahnke_et_al_2010-74) including improved [mood](/wiki/Mood_(psychology)), decreased stress reaction, and decreased anxiety and depression. Most medical studies have only examined psychological factors as secondary goals, although various studies have shown decreases in [cortisol](/wiki/Cortisol) levels, a chemical hormone produced by the body in response to stress. [[74]](#cite_note-Jahnke_et_al_2010-74) China[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=26)] Basic and clinical research in China during the 1980s was mostly descriptive, and few results were reported in [peer-reviewed](/wiki/Peer-review) English-language journals. [[28]](#cite_note-Micozzi2010-28): 22060-22063 Qigong became known outside China in the 1990s, and clinical randomized controlled trials investigating the effectiveness of qigong on health and mental conditions began to be published worldwide, along with systematic reviews. [[28]](#cite_note-Micozzi2010-28): 21792-21798 Challenges[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=27)] Most existing clinical trials have small sample sizes and many have inadequate controls. Of particular concern is the impracticality of [double blinding](/wiki/Blinded_experiment) using appropriate sham treatments, and the difficulty of placebo control, such that benefits often cannot be distinguished from the [placebo effect](/wiki/Placebo_effect). [[28]](#cite_note-Micozzi2010-28): 22278-22306 [[83]](#cite_note-83) Also of concern is the choice of which qigong form to use and how to standardize the treatment or amount with respect to the skill of the practitioner leading or administering treatment, the tradition of individualization of treatments, and the treatment length, intensity, and frequency. [[28]](#cite_note-Micozzi2010-28): 6869-6920, 22361-22370 [[84]](#cite_note-84) Meditation and practiced for [meditation](/wiki/Meditation) and self-cultivation as part of various philosophical and spiritual traditions. As meditation, qigong is a means to still the mind and enter a state of consciousness that brings serenity, clarity, and bliss. [[13]](#cite_note-LWW-13) Many practitioners find qigong, with its gentle focused movement, to be more accessible than seated meditation. [[54]](#cite_note-Garripoli-54) Qigong for self-cultivation can be classified in terms of traditional Chinese philosophy: Daoist, Buddhist, and Confucian. Martial arts applications[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=29)] The practice of qigong is an important component in both [internal](/wiki/Neijia) and [external](/wiki/External_martial_arts) style [Chinese martial arts](/wiki/Chinese_martial_arts). [[13]](#cite_note-LWW-13) Focus on qi is considered to be a source of power as well as the foundation of the [internal style](/wiki/Neijia) of martial arts (Neijia). [T'ai Chi Ch'uan](/wiki/T%27ai_Chi_Ch%27uan), [Xing Yi Quan](/wiki/Xing_Yi_Quan), and [Baguazhang](/wiki/Baguazhang) are representative of the types of Chinese martial arts that rely on the concept of qi as the foundation. [[85]](#cite_note-85) Extraordinary feats of martial arts prowess, such as the ability to withstand heavy strikes ( [Iron Shirt](/wiki/Iron_Shirt), ) [[86]](#cite_note-86)[ [page and qigong[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Qigong&action=edit§ion=30)] [T'ai practiced [internal](/wiki/Neijia) [martial style](/wiki/Chinese_martial_arts) based on the theory of [taiji](/wiki/Taiji_(philosophy)), closely associated with qigong, and typically involving more complex choreographed movement coordinated with breath, done slowly for health and training, or quickly for self-defense. Many scholars consider t'ai chi ch'uan to be a type of qigong, traced back to an origin in the seventeenth century. In modern practice, qigong typically focuses more on health and meditation rather than martial applications, and plays an important role in training for t'ai chi ch'uan, in particular used to build strength, develop breath control, and increase vitality depth"](https://nccih.nih.gov/health/taichi/introduction.htm).
